thread.title: Who will be Brian Cashman’s new right-hand man?
thread.title_full: Who will be Brian Cashman’s new right-hand man? | New York Post

author: George A. King III
title: Who will be Brian Cashman’s new right-hand man?
text:
When Brian Cashman chairs the upcoming professional scouts meeting he may or not have Billy Eppler’s replacement on hand.
What the Yankees’ general manager will have is trusted scouts Tim Naehring and Jay Darnell in the room.
When Eppler, Cashman’s former assistant GM, was recently named the Angels’ GM, a buzz circulated that Naehring and Darnell would follow Eppler to California.
“That’s not true,’’ Cashman said Saturday. “They are under contract.’’
As for who replaces Eppler, who was Cashman’s assistant for four years and with the Yankees for 11, Cashman is working on it.
“I am thinking of a lot of different concepts,’’ Cashman said. “I have to talk to Hal [Steinbrenner].’’
This past week Cashman told The Post’s Joel Sherman he isn’t opposed to hiring from within, but was going to look outside as well.
Because of Eppler’s background is scouting — he was the Yankees’ pro scouting director from 2006-2011 — former Yankees outfielder Kevin Reese’s name has been mentioned. Reese spent this past season as the Yankees director of pro scouting.
Steve Martone, the manager of professional scouting, also could be in play. Michael Fishman, who heads the analytical operations, has an assistant GM title.
While Cashman searches for Eppler’s replacement, decisions have to be made on manager Joe Girardi’s coaching staff. The contracts of bench coach Rob Thomson, first base coach Tony Pena, hitting coach Jeff Pentland expire at the end of the month. Pitching coach Larry Rothschild has another year left and bullpen coach Gary Tuck has an option that is his.
“I haven’t even talked to Joe,’’ Cashman said of Girardi, who Friday said he hadn’t started to think about what the 2016 staff would look like.
As for Naehring and Darnell, they are integral parts of the Yankees’ scouting system. Naehring’s reports on Didi Gregorius when he was with the Diamondbacks were strong and encouraged the club to make the deal. Darnell routinely appears at games in which pitchers who might be moved at the July 31 trade deadline are working.
